Award.AwardTitle: Analytic Aspects of L-functions and Related Problems
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal is centered on new approaches to tackle problems concerning analytic aspects of automorphic L-functions, and their intrinsic connnection to various equidistribution problems in Number Theory, especially the quantitative and effective results in the mass equidistribution properties of Hecke eigenforms on arithmetic surfaces, as well as its higher dimensional generalizations.

The equidistribution problems have their origin from mathematical physics and quantum mechanics, and are well connected to other major areas in mathematics. The rich interplay and interaction of ideas across different fields lie at the heart of the current project.
Because of these distinctive features the research project proposed here are also ideal for training and engaging postdoctoral researchers and Ph.D. students in a vibrant and important research area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our projects yield new and effective results on the natural density and the first occurence of the primes for which the generalized Ramanujan conjecture is true for the Hecke eigenvalues of Maass forms. Our results shed light to this important conjecture central to the theory of automorphic forms and number theory. We have also achieved optimal (positive proportion) nonvanishing result for the central L-values of Hecke eigenforms with large individual weight, which strenthens and refines the previous best-known results. It also provides insights into the long-standing question on the simultaneous nonvanishing of these values twisted by quadratic characters, which has been so far studied only conditionally under the generalized Riemann Hypothesis. Another outcome of our projects is to obtain optimal bound for the 4-th norm of dihedral Maass forms arising from the automorphic induction of Hecke characters of the real quadratic fields. This is a special case of a famous conjecture predicting all 4-th norms of Maass forms should be essentially bounded, which is motivated by random wave models and has implication to quantum mechanics and mathematical physics.

  Our projects provide exciting sources and interesting topics for training Ph.D. students and postdocs in a vibrant research field. 5 students under my supervision have conducted their thesis research closely related to the main themes of the projects, and have successfully obtained their Ph.D. degrees.
